Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description: LaPhonso Ellis missed a potential game-winning 3-pointer and the Washington Wizards held on to defeat the Miami Heat, 82-80, and extend their season-high winning streak to four games.
article.headline: Suddenly hot Wizards win fourth straight

images.name: Jordan, Michael 011212 inline
images.caption: Michael Jordan and the Wizards have won four straight games.

article.linkText: Newly confident Wizards edge Heat for fourth straight win
article.story:
WASHINGTON (AP) -- The Washington Wizards were ahead by two points, but the Miami Heat had the ball with 11 seconds to play. The Wizards gathered in their huddle, and something unusual happened. "We all looked in each other's eyes," guard Richard Hamilton said. "And said, `We're going to win the game."' This year's Wizards are a more confident bunch than in previous seasons, and they didn't let the Heat anywhere near the basket on the final possession. LaPhonso Ellis' desperation 3-pointer hit the rim just before the buzzer as the Washington won its fourth straight, 82-80 on Wednesday night. "I've been here three years," Hamilton said. "We'd be up in the fourth quarter and let the lead slip away. Tonight, we started to grow." The Wizards lost 10 games last season when leading after three quarters. This year, they are 8-0. They are also 6-2 since Michael Jordan declared, "We stink," following a loss at Cleveland and have left the patsies of the league behind. "It's not just four in a row," Jordan said. "Ever since we lost eight in a row, I think guys are starting to accept roles. We're starting to feed off each other." Jordan had 25 points, seven assists and six rebounds in 34 minutes. He made 9 of 23 shots, but his supporting cast continues to improve: Hamilton scored 23 points, and rookie Brendan Haywood had 11 rebounds. "At the beginning of the year, I didn't really fit in," Hamilton said. "I didn't know what they wanted me to do. Now they just play me, that's all I ask." The Wizards hadn't beaten the Heat at home since December 1997, a string of six straight, but this Miami team is tied with Chicago for the league's worst record. Their 20-game start (4-16) is their worst since 1989-90, the franchise's second season in the league. "We just can't get any consistency," coach Pat Riley said. "The first 2½ quarters were absolutely horrendous." Miami nearly overcame a 15-point, second-half deficit. The Wizards scored just 11 points and made only four field goals in the fourth quarter, but the Heat couldn't take full advantage. Alonzo Mourning missed a dunk off a missed shot that could have tied it at 80 with 3:10 remaining, and he also missed two free throws with 1:33 to go and Washington leading by four. Eddie Jones cut the lead to 82-80 with 58 seconds remaining. Jordan then missed a 16-footer, but the Wizards saved the rebound. Tyronn Lue missed a 3-pointer with 16 seconds remaining, and the Heat got the rebound and called timeout to set up the final play. But the Wizards defense kept the ball well beyond the perimeter, with Lue hounding Jones, leaving Ellis to launch a rainbow with the clock running down. Jim Jackson scored 18 points to lead the Heat, but he was also driven to distraction by Jordan. Jackson complained bitterly that Jordan was pushing off with the elbow in the first half and was called for a technical in the third quarter when he argued a foul called when he partially blocked one of Jordan's jump shots. In the first quarter, Jordan attracted four Heat defenders on a drive to the paint late in the first quarter, so he dished to Jahidi White for the dunk. Jordan and Hamilton were a terrific twosome in the opening minutes as the Wizards built a 16-7 lead. Former Washington guard Rod Strickland, booed every time he touched the ball in his first game back at the MCI Center, led an 8-0 run to cut the lead to one, and the teams kept trading runs until the Wizards were up by nine again, 35-26, late in the second quarter and 49-40 at the break.

Game notes
Strickland, who spent five troubled seasons in Washington, said he had no bitter feelings about his ex-team. "It's just one of those situations that didn't work out," Strickland said. "For the last couple of years, it was tough, and you just moved on." ... Mourning also got a technical while claiming he was pushed under the basket by White. Riley ventured several feet onto the court to support his player, but no further call was made. ... The Wizards had a five-game winning streak last season, but it counted for more than a quarter of the team's 19 wins.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
